column4: Quite hard to find, but well worth persevering. This museum has displays of the animals and people of the Northwest Territory. Also, the cafe is excellentr!

Looking for something to do on down time and saw this on Trip Advisor.Exhibits are very nicely laid out. I love the fact that there are specific rooms for most of the displays. Loads of information on plaques, large displays and audio information.I am from Canada but learned a ton of History walking through this Museum.Spot on!

I went there expecting to be less than an hour but I was almost 3 hours. It is really well laid out and gives a real insight as to how the NWT came to exist and the hardships the earlier settlers experienced. This to me was time extremely well spent.By the way, the restaurant is highly recommended by the...

The exhibits are very well laid out and gave us lots of information on the aboriginal people of the north. The story and video of the moose hide canoe was amazing. It was really an eye opener to be able to look at how the people and animals survive and thrive in such harsh conditions. Well worth a visit, especially...

I was greeted by one of the receptionists, who was enthusiastic about telling me what kind of exhibits were on at the time, their hours, and where to start. A map of the centre was provided, and help got me oriented. Definitely worth the donation to learn all sorts of things north. Definitely makes me want to stay and explore...
Beautifully designed building with interesting and informative exhibits - be sure to make time for lunch or a snack at the Museum Cafe.
The Mayors of Yellowknife and of Edmonton hosted a luncheon the other day at the museum cafe. Wonderful location, great room, great food. I'm looking for a reason to host my own event there.
good introduction of local culture, recommend to go there for 1st day. layout is easy to follow and display is surprisingly good.

Surprisingly extensive presentations, lots to see and reflect on. We caught the free tour, guide was very informative, a bit of a raconteur. Fun kids area with lots of play and dress up opportunities. Finish up with a snack or meal at the Museum Cafe.

I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this museum. We went on our last day in Yellowknife to escape the -15C cold outside. This museum has a good amount of exhibits to spend an hour or more but its not too overwhelming. There is a good balance of exhibits on the land, animals, history and culture.
Informative exhibits on history, culture, and nature, set up beautifully so you can have a quick overview or really dive in and learn a lot. Highly recommended, you will learn and see new things.

It was a great place to visit and understand more about the aboriginal cultures. specially the two rooms of animals (with a polar bear and a musk) and the room regarding the culture are of great interest. Totally recommended. The museum is open til 9 pm on thursdays and the rest of the days until 5 pm. It is within...
Must do whilst in Yellowknife. Provides you with a good background on Yellowknife and it's heritage.A number of very interesting displays .Great cafe for coffee or a light lunch.
This indeed is a museum highlighting the north. Have a great kids play area on the main floor. The "cafe" is highly spoken of in the local area. Unfortunately is not open on Sunday(cafe).

This was a great museum with lots of things to see. I spent a couple hours here and didn't even get to all the exhibits. The best part of it all was that there is no entrance fee! I love that with museums because then you can come and go as you please and don't feel like you need to...
We were lucky to joined in a morning tour guild, the gentleman was really informative and we learnt so much more NWT history and geographic knowledge from him.
The museum is smaller than what we expected. The facts about the native people, their culture and their life challenges.
Had lunch. Nice place for lunch and a visit. Beautiful building. Worth a visit. Lots of information, displays, artifacts.
Very nice small size museum with very good quality exhibits. We spent 2 hours here self learning about the native and their culture as well as the animals they hunts.
It's a small place compared to big city museums but it still contained lots of information about Yellowknife & life up north.Worth a visit while I'm town!
A beautiful building with multiple rooms that gives the visitor an overview of the people, resources, geology and development of the NWT
I enjoyed this museum. It has displays that are put together very nicely. I enjoyed reading about the early history of the area.
Super interesting to learn about the local culture. The exhibits were beautiful and well maintained!

New building. Well-done exhibits. Learned a lot about the mineral and animal wealth of the region. Also exhibits on the people, their culture and their language, but did not have enough time to do that justice.
The center is a great place to find out more about the city. Be aware it opens only between 11 am to 2:30 pm.
it is a beautiful museum located in central Yellowknife. The staff are great, the displays top notch, and informative to boot! A definite must see!

The museum is relatively small but has exhibitions of the region and its inhabitants and explorers. Very nice. I very much enjoyed the exhibit about the Norther cultures and diverse adaptions to the different food sources - brilliant. Although the caribou seem to struggle for some reasons, good to hear the polar bears and muskox have increased in large numbers...
Thus has an abundance of arts and culture. Very broad range of colonial history with mining. Wonderful representation of the Norths culture, people, plants and wildlife.

It's awesome place to get some introduction about NWT. I like all the exhibits; the animals look real and the information is thorough. I highly recommend this place for family with children. The best thing is free admission.

Didn't expect we could see so much at this museum. There are lots of interesting, informative display and exhibits depicting the history of the aboriginal and the Northern Territories. Can't ask for more from this free admission museum. Highly recommend to family with young children and visitors who want to spend an hour or two during the day at Yellowknife.
We recently held a reception at this venue, and it was beautiful. The staff were friendly, helpful, and receptive; the art displays were incredibly well set up and filled with emotion.

This museum is a very well done tribute to life in Northern Canada. They have a wide range of displays featuring a number of different aspects of the history and development of the north and Yellowknife specifically. I was very pleased how they gave very significant and prominent attention to all of the aboriginal people groups that form the foundation...

The museum is free with some neat exhibits. I loved the native bead word on display. There are also some cool pieces from the history of air travel to the north. Worth the time and a nice reprieve from the cold.

A very fun and educational way to spend 2-3 hours. You learn a lot about the history of the place and some interesting artifacts. Being from the lower 48 US, it was interesting to see how humanity found ways to survive and thrive in one of the harshest climates on earth. The desolation of the NWT still has me in...
We toured this amazing facility while on our tour of Yellowknife this past August. It is amazing. Informative. Depicts a true picture of our north. A must see.
It's a very nice, well organized and informative museum. It covers local history, native culture. I learnt a lot
This place is free admission, and they have free tours on Wed/Fri/Sat at 11:45AM. It was sufficient to walk through the museum without a tour; the displays were quite informative and interactive.

Nice small museum for Yellowknife district. Lots of local display and information. A very quiet and comfortable place to spend an hour or two in the afternoon. Staffs are friendly and local artists on location to show off their talents.
Visiting the museum is a must if you want to explore the Northeast Territories. There are many precious exhibits. It is also a good education centre.
Excellent exhibits and very educational. While there make time to dine in the Museum Café - the food is delicious.
Excellent overview of the culture, people, and natural attributes of the Territiores! It is well worth a visit to see and 'experience the development of the North

My wife and I walked up the paved 3km Flame Lake trail to this prominent building sitting at the north end. It opened at 10:30AM and was free to enter. After noting the restrooms on the entry floor we walked up to the cafe and noted its restroom. From here we walked down the beautiful wooden arched hall to enter...
There's a lot to see and do in this place. History. Artifacts and information. We have enjoyed and stayed a few hours in this center.

Well done museum with exhibits on mining, aboriginal settlement, and others. The aviation exhibit is excellent with a short film showing how aviation opened up the NWT and highlighting the pioneer spirit. There's a children's section for active play.

This is a must for anyone visiting Yellowknife. You need to allot a few hours to appreciate the displays. The centre gives you a comprehensive view of the land, peoples, and the animals, prehistoric and present day of the Northwest Territories.

Arrived and had many many allergy questions, staff was very helpful and knowledgable. Had an amazing lunch, it was awesome, very generous servings.Nice and bright area to eat. Staff is wonderful!!!!! Thank-you. Continued on with viewing the museum and as usual very interesting. Loved the TP

Interesting architecture. Beautiful location. Nice display of local artifacts, regional animals (stuffed) and demonstration videos add to the experience. There were some very nice art installations: large stone carvings and paintings - my residential school experience. Very moving. Also on site was a very nice cafe serving lunch. Very busy at noon. Try to arrive before or after 12 noon.

The building is clean, bright, and interesting. Great for families with young children. The play area for kids never disappoints. The Museum Cafe serves great food too, but wish they were open on Sunday when we went back.

they really need to advertise this museum differently. we went there and LOVED it there is fabulous displays and interesting exhibits , natural history lovers will enjoy the visit and anyone interested in northern history from expedition, fur trading and arts. a very worth while visit. we spent 2.5 hours there and it was not enough

When I heard that there wasn't an admission fee, I worried that it would not be all that nice. The folks at the visitor's center said it was worth going to, and it did not disapoint! Cool history facts, and they talk about how the natives used each animal that they hunted! some Great exhibits for sure! And good food...

We spent a good portion of a morning here. The exhibits are wonderful. I loved the sculptures. There is a ton of information in a small building. You definitely get an education on Yellowknife and surrounding area as well as the people of the North.It is a beautiful location with walking trails close by, you can walk from the...

We came to Yellowknife with the sole purpose of aurora viewing. Hence, we woke up late, found a place to walk a bit, then have our dinner and prepare for the night.With this in mind, the centre would be a good place to learn about the history of Yellowknife, including the transport system, the people, the animals and various...

This is one of the best Museums we have been to! The detail of information is incredible! You walk away having a new appreciation of life in the north!The security is over zealous in the rules of not touching (which I firmly believe in)even if you point close they will be on you! To make their point they will...
Lots of information about the formation of Yellowknife and the opening up of the North West Territories.
We were fortunate enough today to be part of a guided tour of the museum... A not to miss experience. The displays, the narrative, so well done. A 1 hr well worth while. Thank you.

The quality of the displays, dioramas, videos and information provided here are excellent. I wish we had more time to stay but were pressed to make a flight. Ideally you'd have 1.5 hours to spend here. There is so much to see and watch, very educational and well done. And admission is by donation!

First of all, I am not a museum person. But my sister insisted that I should give it a try. Well, it was definitely worth the time. Not only was the exhibit interesting, it was free and you can get lots of suovenirs for free also. I got the cd which shows the city of Yellowknife, a Yellowknife pin, and...

The history of this area as well as the flora and fauna of this magnificent area as well as it's rich history are all on display here. From mining (geology) to aviation this museum has numerous informative exhibits which shouldn't be missed. The dioramas of various mammals and birds of the Northwest Territories are on display here and are thoughtfully...
My husband and I really enjoyed the time we spent here. Our tour guide Jean was so knowledgeable and interesting and he was very willing to answer the many, many questions I asked during the tour!

one of my friends lives in Yellowknife and said, Let's go to the museum for lunch. I was so absolutely taken by this place. The food was amazingly well done. The menu choices were amazing. it tid not surprise me to see the place fill up by noon with customers wanting to eat.After we had our wonderful lunch we...

What an interesting place to wander about. We had personal tour and came away with a lot more knowledge for the area. The café was also good and our tour guide an expert in his field. He didn't rush us and tried to answer all our questions. The best part of this tour you would think would be costly but...

Had an excellent tour this morning at the Prince of Wales Museum. Not only was the museum very interesting but our tour guide Mike was fantastic. Best tour I have been on in my life as it was very interactive and informative.

This museum was very interesting and informative. The interactive activities were awesome. I loved the moose hide tanning demonstrations and the spear throwing was so much fun! Mike was an amazing tour guide, best one I've ever had!! thanks mike!
Learn about the history of the land and the people of NWT. See art exhibits and eat at the cafe. A great half day experience - time well spent.

Usually you have to go to London U.K. or Washington D.C. to be able to explore museums for free but low and behold this fantastic northern museum is free of charge. It has some real interesting exhibits and definitely deserves an hour or more to view them all. I was really impressed by the art display on the impact on...

Quite a range of exhibits that give a nice overview of life and history in NWT. Great for families on a budget and there is a kids interactive area. Our daughter and friend were able to a scavenger hunt throughout the museum which helped keep them involved.

This museum has stunning architecture, much like the legislative building. The arches made the place feel so airy. The cafeteria served excellent food. As for the displays- there was a wonderful carver being featured. I am afraid the museum displays were overshadowed by the architecture, food and carvings.

Liked the way the museum's collections were set up, and even though we are older and don't have small children, it was nice to see what an effort had been put into making a fantastic play area with costumes and houses to explore.
Beautiful displays of first nations art, way of life, and wildlife and history. Cafe was also very good.
An amazing display of early life in the Territories, wildlife, Mining, transportation, art and culture. Exhibits are well displayed with good explanations. Not to be missed.

Stopped to get info on what our options were in Yellowknife.The staff were excellent, helpful, friendly. Cute stuff to look at and buy. A cross between a museum and gift shop. Lots of brochures. Overall great info and a recommended stop early in your trip

I combined the visitors centre, the legislative Assembly and the Museum in a morning tour/activity and it was great! A beautiful collection of northern history, artifacts and art laid out in a beautiful building and best of all - free! My favourite price! Various displays ranging from transportation in the north, animal life, minerals, Indigenous culture and more. Some of...
Didn't have much time, but it was worth the visit to learn more about the history of NWT. Beautiful exhibits and very comfy chairs!
The museum provides a good overview of the Northwest Territories. There is a terrific play area for preschoolers that fits in with the theme of the museum. The cafe is opened Monday-Friday.

This museum is awesome..there are many great displays featuring wildlife and the ways of northern cultures. The children's play area is fantastic as it gives kids a fun way to experience the museum. There is also a great cafe.
Great family spot with a nice cafe to eat in! Lots to see and its Free! Fun scavenger hunt for the kids and tons to see
There is no charge to visit this museum and it has truly outstanding exhibits. The giant moose hide boat and the video describing how it was made are worth the trip alone!

Nice setting? excellent location...we can visit there from the bus routing. We got off the bus # B route and off by the supermarket. Then we walked toThe visitor center .__biz=MjM5MzgxMjI2OA==&mid=2650968610&idx=1&sn=96ed7913f5feb54f91a7aa213a838194&scene=1&srcid=0512cAwuGHGTGCRwFR8Ngu5X&from=groupmessage&isappinstalled=0#wechat_redirect

Great little museum! Went on the 10:30 free tour with Brian and he was fantastic! Very knowledgable across all area's of exhibits plus much more! Would highly recommend taking a few hours to check this little gem out.
Great displays and wonderful tour guide. Each display was so informative. Liked the film about the moose skin boat.
A great stop in Yellowknife. Has interesting exhibits with lots to learn about the City. Free to the public.
We found the entire museum to be very informative...the cafeteria was such a great place to have lunch.
Was good! Adding life experience to your diary and memorable history of northern life style of the pass.
A must visit when in YK. great location easily walkable or bikeable to. Impressive displays, you really get to understand life in the north
the exhibition is good. we learned a lot about aboriginal history in Yellowknife. there is a coat rack beside the entrance, so visitors don't need to hold the heave down coat during the tour.
Amazing place to visit our history and our land. It's FREE so take in all the beautiful memories and pictures you can take.

A wonderful museum filled with interesting exhibits that tell the history of the NTW and the aboriginal people. Also, yo can learn about the native animals that live or once lived in the area. The museum has a wonderful cafe with fantastic food, so I suggest you plan your visit around lunch time, but please beware - it gets very...
This museum had history of Yellowknife and the people who lived there first, information about local animals, and they even had art from a local artist! Loved it!
Best Museum in town. Should take about an hour to do. Short walk from the Explorer Hotel. 10 Minute walk from downtown. Stop at the Northern Frontier Visitors Centre enroute

Very interesting way to learn about the area you are visitng. Try to arrive for lunch at the Museum Cafe (open from 11-2) which is very good. A great way to pass a couple of hours during the day time of a Yellowknife winter
We had a small gap of time between checking out of our hotel and our flights home so we stopped by for a quick look. So glad we did. The galleries present history in the most interesting fashion.
Lots of interesting exhibits and history to explore! Well worth a visit to learn more about Yellowknife and the NW Territories history.

This museum is free, but it's a good idea to bring money to donate because they have put so much into it. It is a great way to learn about the areas history. They also have a café that is not always open, but the manager there is so friendly. We thoroughly appreciate the time we were able to spend...

The museum is a nice little gem that presents several distinct and nicely set-up areas. There are exhibits on local geology and mining (gold ore doesn't look like gold!), the town's history, the ice-age biology of the area (complete with some awesome models of mammoth and mastodon teeth and a giant beaver's skull), and the history, culture, and crafts of...

Provides a nice sampling of life 'up North' for a GREAT price (by donation). Leisurely, informative, but not overwhelming. You can spend an hour, or two, depending how much time you have. We loved the visiting exhibit of incredible sculptures by the artist, Abraham Anghik Ruben, which opened the afternoon of our visit. You really must make time to eat...
great informative place, you can find a lot historic information, original peaces. There is also restaurant that everybody recommended, but i did not try (I had already other plans).
Educational, informative & cultural. Not to be missed while visiting Yellowknife .Excellent showvcase of the place. Just across Explorer hotel.

Not only was the museum interesting and informative of the culture but the food was outstanding! The only complaint was that my bison burger was a little fishy. Other than that I highly recommend this place!
Nice please to look at the Aboriginal culture. Interactive and fun place for family with kids. I had a great time there.

This is a must stop place for all tourists to visit. Not only are the displays excellent, but the museum is free. The special section for children would keep them busy for quite some time. Once you have finished viewing the displays, you can relax in the café for good coffee and great food.

We decided to tour the museum on a rainy day and it didn't disappoint. Lots of really great exhibits that tell the story of the local history with some great stuff for kids including a play area where they could dress up.

The Heritage center is a great place to learn about the culture of Yellowknife, Canada. The displays are professional and there is a section there for the children to learn. I like the art displayed as well s the video of the elk boat. We also had lunch there and it was delicious. Have the ginger cookies!
Very interesting, wife especially enjoyed the many exhibits and informative informative exhibit explanations. The building moose hide canoe video was interesting.
We were here on business, so it was nice to see some local culture. This museum is a wealth of artifacts and exhibits. I'm so glad we took a couple hours out to visit. It was worth it.

Great collections and well planned out museum. Looks very clean and new. Loved that there's a "treasure hunt for the kids" while they go through-look to the right when you first arrive to pick it up. When done, the kids get a small price from the info desk for completing it. Was wonderful, self-guided and organizes well. I learned so...
Great displays of wild animals, people's cultures and history in the north west territory. Restaurant provides good food and nice views.
Very attractive building in a beautiful setting. Well laid out and organised giving a good overview of the history and culture of this vast region.

I was recommended to stop in and check this place out, and it really was worth the stop. You get to learn about the culture of the First Nations, and see some cool artifacts and learn some history. Definitely worth going to see if you're already in Yellowknife.

After the aurora this was the highlight of our stay in Yellowknife. The exhibits are of very high quality and very informative. The art was amazing. The bison stew was outstanding. A must-see attraction.
I was told by the one person that I knew in Yellowknife that the museum was a must-see an i was not disappointed - beautiful facility and collections

This facility offers visitors a comprehensive glimpse into the unique history of the peoples and activity of the Northwest Territory.There are fine galleries, wonderfully curated, highlighting facets of life ranging from transportation to the wildlife of the area; my personal favorite is the gallery highlighting northern carvings, and the creation and manufacture of the buffalo-skin boat.Wonderful!
Surely feel that it' not just museum without dedication.Good place for everyone even child, and there's also TripAdvisor's 3rd graded restaurant - museum cafe!
If you like museums give this one a go. Great place to learn all about the NWT and Yellowknife in particular. We really enjoyed it. They also have a wonderful cafe where you can get lunch.

This museum is a must see, preferably early in your trip. You'll learn the history of the region and see historical items. Just an hour or so is all you need to get a better understanding of the area.
We originally came here for their excellent lunches and thoroughly enjoyed all the exhibits. Beautiful building and great resource for the community.
Call in for lunch then check out the exhibits. I'ts a short walk from most hotels and quite the experience walking through the -25 degree cold to get there.

This is an excellent place to learn for free about the area, both Yellowknife and Northwest Territories. The place is very well organized. It has amazing displays: wildlife, historical, mining, etc. It has both static and interactive, multimedia displays.I learned a lot about the area. We spent about 2 hours there.My 9 year old son loved it too....

If you're into museums and stuff like that, it would be really nice to visit the heritage center. It's really close to the visitor center, so consider visiting them altogether(along with legislative assembly building maybe).
If you come to Yellowknife it worth visiting here for sure! It has a great display of local culture and artist.

A great place to spend a quiet afternoon learning about Canadian history and the history of Yellowknife.The most interesting parts, I found, were about the Native and Western interactions and horrible treatment of the native peoples that unfortunately continues to this day.I learned a lot.
a very informative and cosy museum. a good walk from the town to the museum to admire the winter view around.
Very nice facility with some neat exhibits. It primarily focuses on the aboriginal culture. I would have like to see more exhibits on the mining history and white exploration of the area.

We visited this museum during our trip to Yellowknife. The museum itself is not large, but displays the history of Northern exploration, indigenous people, and wild animals. It is a nice place to visit.
Lots of displays including polar bears.... Very informative! It's close to the Legislative assesbly building, walking distance!
Wonderful facility, amazing carvings currently in the feature gallery, but that is a temporary exhibit. Terrific presentation in various media.
We were killing time between meetings in downtown Yellowknife. Its a lovely space, lots of interesting things to look at. Good summary of the YK area.
Beautifully laid out, lots of interesting items to do with history, culture, wildlife, settlements, geography. Definitely spend an hour or two here.
Very informative with interactive displays. Great way to spend an hour or two. Kids would enjoy the animal displays I'm sure.

I wish more museums were like this. It wasn't pretentious but a welcoming, interesting and interactive chance to learn more about Yellowknife, it's people and their history.I really enjoy that it seemed lots of the exhibits were donated and came with personal stories.This was a fantastic stop & having looked at/read everything it only took a few hours...

The PWHC is a must see for both visitors and residents alike. You learn all about the people and the culture of the North. There are also special displays and Fun Sunday events. Lunch at the museum cafe is also a great option
Always wonderful service and food! Handy to the exhibits so you can take a well deserved break. The Chef has daily creations and the price is right!
Great information from the staff about the different trails and things to see.Don't forget to get your photo with the sign at the "line"
This place is worthwhile visiting. The museum provides you with an interesting walk through of the history of the North West Territory's history. Only downside was that the canteen was very messy.
A thoroughly pleasant experience, giving a lot of information on the north which I had not learned in school. Also, it is a family-friendly centre, with hands-on experiences for children.
We found this to be a fabulous museum. A lot of history, culture & art work. One of the exhibits was closed but still plenty to see.
very informative about the history of Canada NW region, free admission ! recommend to at least spend 1 to 2 hours here
Admission is free. A wonderful place to see more of the Northern Heritage. Well organized and nice setup.
Beautiful informative little museum. The biggest surprise was the fantastic restaurant. I had an excellent lunch......could be one of the best in town
Fantastic place - well executed and informative exhibits. Great cafe. Easy to get to from downtown Yellowknife. Near City Hall and a pretty park right on the water.
A surprisingly thorough museum for being so far north. Excellent exhibits, including rotating ones featuring local artists.

This free museum is incredible. We spent about 2 hours there and could have spent another 2. Information on the area's history, wildlife, and residents, plus some sculpture and art (when we visited in 9/2015).
Did a full tour of exhibits which were very informative and the building structure is amazing itself. a really good feeling in there. Had two excellent meals there.

The displays are very thoughtful, interactive and presented in a fun way. There's not a huge amount to look at (you can do the whole museum in an hour) but it gives a great insight into northern lifestyle and has a fun area for kids to play in. I don't have any kids but I would have loved to play...

Oh my gosh, what an amazing place! It took a couple of hours to go through and it really held our interest. I would happily go back. Not a place to miss! For a place as small as Yellowknife, they should be proud of this amazing site!
Don't miss this when you are in Yellowknife. A nice display of the northern heritage and history. There is a fun interactive section for kids too.

The museum is quite compact but very interesting. It is wonderful to learn about the traditional way of living in the Northern hemisphere. Some displays are hands on, others come with a clear oral description. A great place for young and old. No entrance fee- very friendly people. Upstairs is an amazing little restaurant with great food and a beautiful...
Free, interesting, educational. I didn't have a lot of time so my visit was a little rushed but I still had time to enjoy it and learn a lot about the area.

This is a wonderful museum and it is free (admission by donation). I like history and the archives of the Northwest Territories are here. I wish I had the time when I was there to delve into those. I like history and I am particular interested in things like what once took place at Hay Camp in Wood Buffalo National...

Free admission. Donations accepted. Small compared to other big city museums, but good information. Kids enjoyed the visit. Able to do scavenger hunt and received some postcards at the end of the visit. Learned a few things about the North. Try their Cafe. Excellent food with reasonable prices.

This very small museum has some excellent exhibits highlighting the natural history of the north and the people who share the land with the wildlife. Excellent dioramas. When we were there, we had the privilege of seeing a special exhibit by a renowned Inuit artist Abraham Anghik Ruben. The museum is free. Don't miss lunch in the café...a special experience....

Wonderful place to visit. Take a tour if you can. It seems that few do, so we had a private tour but that was kindly tailored to our interests. Don't miss the Last Moose Boat Exhibit and movie - very well done. We loved the porcupine quilling demonstration, and the restaurant was amazing. Slowish service, but worth waiting for, just...

Visit the archives and ask how they are funded. It is alarming to see the federal government is not supporting this valuable service. We are losing our history. However, the centre itself is a well run, organized facility. Wonderful northern information. Enjoyed the pilot section.

Anyone visiting this terrific city should take every opportunity to learn a little more about the history and evolution of the "northern way", and the Northern Heritage Centre is a very fine place to explore.It offers galleries and explanations of northern wildlife, mineral resources, indigenous communities, transportation and contemporary history; an invaluable addition to the understanding of the delightful...

As a bed and Breakfast owner I hear from tourist their thoughts about the museum on an going bases. All the guests comment on how modern it is, how informative it is and how well kept the displays are. And those who have made return visits comment on the fact the displays are always changing. If you want to know...

Has donation system with no set fee to get in. Some great info on local & regional history. Obvious pride in the exhibits. Apparently what is on display changes but what they did have was great. Nice 'What I Saw' photo gallery with an information blurb by the photographer. Has a cafe (never tried) and is well situated.
Great displays, interesting mix of natural, cultural and indigenous history. Highly recommended. Also has a great cafetereria
This is a great place to bring children. I have been here many times in summer and in winter. The path through the trees from the Visitor Centre is pleasant.
Well worth taking the time to tour through the Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre. The room with the sculptures is phenomenal - we were really glad we visited the centre.

Beautiful architectural building on a lake. Exhibits are informative and it really gives you a good idea of the culture and history of YK. A Metis weaver, Ria was demonstrating her art on the day I visited.
Very informative and entertaining. Free guided tour is a great way to get the most of the visit.The only problem is the limited parking space.
Lots of neat exhibits of animals, art, and culture. We spent an hour, but you could easily spend two or more.No gift shop, so you have to go to the visitor's center for that.
We were expecting more culture when we planned our trip to Yellowknife. So when we went to the museum it was nice to experience culture, history and the northern life.

This museum was great! Free entrance to the museum which is great since Yellowknife is so expensive. The exhibits were fantastic and interactive. Highly recommend. The museum cafe we stopped to have a coffee and dessert- also worth doing (cheap).
Loved the beautiful building its self and the wonderful displays of life in the north. A Most excellent gallery of stone carvings. Very interesting very worth a visit!

By donation. Several amazing exhibits, including that of the Steppe Bison. It was buried in permafrost for more than 13,000 years, so when it came out, it still had some skin, flesh and hair. Professional interpretive panels explain this animal and compares to modern bison.Also an exhibit hall for Indigenous use of animals, including examples of hide clothing with...
Theres some pretty interesting stuff here but wasn't blown away. I was in and out in just over 30 minutes and that was enough. I heard the food here is really good, but a Pepsi runs you 3$...

This is a very interesting place with all sorts of exhibits covering a wide range of Yellowknife/NWT history and life. It is well worth the visit even if you only have a short amount of time to walk through. Art, sculptures, videos, a moose skin canoe, mining, aviation, winter life, etc...it has it all.
It is a must visit when you are in Yellowknife. The exhibits are one of a kind and very well presented.
A great spot to start your visit to Yelloknife. This spot has the info you need to plan your visit plus lots of historical information about the area.

I enjoyed seeing the exhibits and learning about northern heritage. Admission is free (donations accepted) and there is a café that is open for lunch. Museum is a short walk from town, near the Frame Lake Trail.

The Centre is centrally located on Frame Lake within a few minutes walk of downtown. It has great information about the human and natural history of the area. My favourite was the exhibition of the old planes and snow machines. Highly recommended for all ages. Great value too as it was free.

I visited the PWNHC on three occasions: for lunch, for a lovely musical performance, and to see the museum's exhibits. All three events were high quality. Chef Chris runs a marvelous restaurant with exquisite food, and Table for Five - in a spectacular setting - was an unexpected treat for someone who grew up with this music. The museum itself...
The dioramas were excellent, the food in the cafeteria was spectacular and the art on display was incredible. Don't miss a visit here

This is a very nicely set up museum. Suitable for people who just want to take a quick look and those who want to linger and get a better understanding of the area, its culture and community. Wide range of exhibits covering topics such as traditional life, economy, settlement and community, art, natural history etc. Restaurant is a must! No...
This museum is well laid out and the exhibits are easy to view and read about the information. Would be great for families and all ages. The animal exhibits are amazing !
Visited the centre to see the work of Abraham Ruben and was not disappointed. Excellent sculptures. It was worth the visit
This museum is amazing...... Don't miss it! There is something for everyone. Right now you can experience the works of a world class carver.

This is a small but very interesting museum to learn about northern life and culture, with many interesting photos, a few pieces of painting, and a small collection of artifacts. But to me the most enjoyable parts are the exhibition of sculptures by Inuvialuit Sculptor Abraham Anghik Ruben, which is running through till early 2016 I believe, and the mooseskin...

This museum is on the Frame Lake trail. They have beautiful audiovisual diorama of northern animals and also northern communities and how they survived. It's not a big museum but there's a lot of information and fun for adults and children alike. There's currently an exhibit by Ruben which is quite lovely. The cafe is only open til 2pm -...

What a great place to discover the North's heritage, kid friendly. Amazing displays. Unique exhibits. Wonderful little café. A great place to bring visitors from out of town. Or just to spend the afternoon with the grandkids.

This is a must see for visitors to Yellowknife. The exhibits are fascinating and the sense of history of the area is well told in stories and exhibits. The staff there were very helpful because it was first time there and I wasn't sure where to go. A morning well spent!

Amazing and well thought thru displays, exhibits and information. Beautiful building nestled in awesome surroundings by the lake. THe whole experience is well worth repeating. And- it's the best place to eat in Yellowknife- hands down!! The menu is always varied- extremely tasteful- unique and fresh. If this place can produce should good meals- what the heck is wrong with...
The heritage centre was really interesting. We learned a lot about life this far north. Most definitely worth a visit. Admission is free.
Informative. Plenty of models and speciemens of wild native animals. Worth spending more time in this quality museum.
A nice compact museum highlighting select aboriginals items - historical, embroidery and art display.

I went there together with 3 tourists who happened to be staying in my hotel shortly before they left for their flights. As I returned to the hotel together with them in a rush, I only had a cursory viewing of the major exhibits there which include specimens of foxes, polar bear and deer-related species and the model of aboriginal...

We loved this very interesting museum in Yellowknife and I spent a significant amount of time absorbing the extensive information on the history and cultures that inhabit it. This was an absolute highlight if you're after some local historical insight!

This museum is compact but very informative and a great introduction to the area - would only take you an hour or so to go through it. I had lunch at the cafe there which is a great place to eat on its own.Definitely a go to attaction while visiting Yellowknife

An treasure in Yellowknife. Friendly accommodating and helpful staff, complete with professional exhibits, a comfortable layout, informative exhibits and a great way to learn about the NWT. If you have a few hour layover at the airport - it's a 5 minute taxi ride and well worth the detour!

My friend and I went there and incidentally, there was an aurora presentation. We sat in and gained more knowledge about aurora. Very interesting.Then we walked around the entire museum. I really enjoyed the presentation and the flow of the display in various sections. Very easy to browse on your own, and read at your own pace without feeling...

A great museum with easy to access information on the environment and peoples of the North. We like the special/temporary displays too. There is always something more to learn when we come to this museum.
The Centre had a variety of Cultural and artistic works with many photos and paintings. It was not so big but well arranged and informative.

While the building itself is well worth a visit, the restaurant is the best kept local secret in town. The restaurant is only open from 11:00 to 3:00 and gets very busy around noon so plan accordingly.We went there four times on a six day trip (it was closed on the week-end) and pretty much "ate the menu" prices...
I like the sample polar bear?other animal? i like the plane and other machine? My friend took pictures even in TP and snow mobile?If there was aboriginal music or video about them will be perfect
it doesn´t take long to go through, but it is very informative and great displayed. worth every second spent.

A compact and well put together facility with oodles of interesting things to see and it's all by donation for the entry fee. We thoroughly enjoyed two hours in the facility. Great place to take kids.
Gorgeous museum which is very informative and with extremely well done displays. Really helps one to understand the history of Yellowknife. Really enjoyed touring it!

Shockingly great exhibits and information at this place. Very cool location and building also. There was a VERY special event called Walking With Our Sisters here that was all about the MANY missing and murdered aboriginal women across Canada. Very well down, brought respect, reverence, and highlighted the importance of this issue to anyone that came through. The volunteers were...
worth to go! you can know more abt yellowknife and the local how to live in previous day. there is funny n informative
A wonderful place. The staff are kind and very well informed about local history and the area. Definitely worth taking the time to visit.
Visited this centre with our family, great to spend an hour or so. Very good broad information. Great for kids. Very warm and welcoming.
A small museum near Frame lake, that show you the history of Yellowknife and with art gallery area. It is worthwhile to spend some time here to know about the city you visiting
If you have only 24 hours and must do something, then sure visit the heritage centre. In and out in about 20 minutes.

Enjoyed the whole centre. It gives you a good idea of the animals and what life was like in this part of Canada. Also a great showcase for northern artists. Had a great showing of Jennifer Walden while we were visiting.

Great place to see the beauties of the North (nature, animals, culture, rocks, etc..) as well as enjoying a wonderful lunch at the Museum Café.The exhibits are great and make you travel through time or the North. Great presentations and a perfect first thing to do when you get up here.You will see what the pionners were up...

Enjoyed visiting this Centre and took the time to read some of the detail in the exhibits. Very informative history of the NWT's and such detail and realism built into the displays... We don't have moose in Australia and standing next to a full sized taxi-dermed one was a great insight.. Even down to the moisture dripping off its fur...

This museum is small but interesting. I helps one understand some of the differences that exist in life in the north, and how it is a combination of new and the traditional.We particularly enjoyed the works of art'

We went last year, in October 2013, and visited for an hour. This year, returning to Yellowknife in September, 2014, we didn't bother.There just wasn't much there. It's worth a quick trip, I don't recall a fee, but don't expect to spend a long time.

A very interesting museum, that provides the visitor with an in depth view of what was, and to some degree is, Canada's last frontier.Unique displays, and a very good restaurant - and to top it off - admission is free. I have visited on 4 occasions and found each visit both enjoyable and informative.

This is a great little museum that is packed with all sorts of things for all ages. It's free. It's interactive and there are hundreds of little tidbits of information. There is a long walking path around Framers Lake near the museum entrance that you can save for another day (note: the complete walk is about 90'+ and the city...

I got this confused with the visitor centre on Trip Advisor. See this! It's really nice and your tax dollars have already paid for it.1500$ Leather chairs are everywhere and almost no one has ever sat in them.
Was very surprised to see how nice this little museum was for being in such a remote area. Definitely worth a visit. Won't take more than an hour two.
Loved this little gem that was unexpected. Different insights into how it all began, how the people lived and some beautiful artwork was displayed

This is a modern facility which packs a number of exhibits into a relatively small space. Every exhibit provides some new insight in the Northwest Territories and it's history.Definitely a must see.Although there is no charge, you can make a donation near the front door. After going through it we did.

A really nice little museum that details the history of the area. Awesome opportunity to see samples of the minerals that put Yellowknife on the map and some of the local animals. The best part is that it's FREE!
The interactive displays were fun! Lunch was excellent. Would return for sure! So much to learn here!

Great variety of exhibits and information. The current art exhibit was gorgeous. like everything in the museum, it reflected the NWT land and culture. Beautiful! Plan to visit near lunch time and eat at the Museum Cafe.flected and
art, history, things to touch and travelling exhibits make this a special place to visit... the building is beautiful and has a great cafe... all it needs is a gift shop

If you are interested in seeing some beautiful northern art, this is the place. A historical perspective on the north. The moose-skin canoe is on display(from the movie in the National. Film Board)Make sure you visit the cafe for coffee ans something sweet

Have been bringing guests to this museum for the past 20 years. Always a favourite .... until now. The place has been gutted! Where are the displays on Dene culture and the mining history? I don't mind the old-town-weaving-from-fur (of my trusty dog) artwork but it is an imposed southern culture not the NWT culture being displayed here. I think...
Great museum. Lots of cool facts and interactive exhibits... Beautiful artwork as well. I would slot about an hour to two to spend in here.

on our visit to Yellowknife we visited all the touristy places. We were bery impressed with the quality of the museum for such a small city. One highlight was the cafe, excellent lunch at a reasonable price.
What a great place to see!A definite must to explore for anyone visiting Yellowknife.There are so many wonderful things in this Centre.

It is a great place to have fun and understand the history of the area. There was so much to see e.g. lots of artifacts, minerals, dioramas, big canoe made of skins by hands, aboriginal lifestyle, etc. You can also try on their aboriginals' clothing ... really worth to go to know more about the aboriginal culture.

Cafe was wonderful - I've travelled a lot in the north, and was surprised to see so many salads on the menu. I really enjoyed my lunch.That wasn't the highlight, though. The whole facility is great, and nice to walk around. I didn't find the staff overwhelmingly friendly or helpful, but the exhibits are really great.

The Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre was only a short walk from the Explorer Hotel we stayed in. We had lunch at the Museum Cafe before paying the Museum a visit. The Museum wasn't huge, but had a good display of the Northern Culture & Natural Surrounding, very interesting and informative.
Don't miss this museum! It is an essential part of a trip to Yellowknife. Informative, well-laid out, and engaging.

I ordered their lunch special .....white fish with salad, fruit, and rice.That salad had so many items in it and the dressing was excellent. It is a crowded place. Many people ordered the ribeye sandwich......a popular order.

We didn't know about this place before our trip, but what a gem! The museum is free (donations welcome) and has exhibits on everything from nature, to mining to first nations. My 6 year old daughter loved it, and so did we!

I am not a museum person per se, but I thoroughly enjoyed myself. You simply must take advantage of this unique setting in the north while you are in Yellowknife. The museum is free and offers fabulous exhibits to keep you interested.

The museum may be small, but it is packed with information on the area. It was interactive...I especially enjoyed creating my own aurora! The lunch was delightful and the chef even came out to talk to us. Very worthwhile to spend some time there to learn about Yellowknife.

We visited this museum in March. It was very interesting, telling us many things about Yelwlowknife history. The little restaurant was nice,a little expensive for lunch but then everything costs more up here in the north. The ginger cookies were amazing.

We particularly enjoyed the environmental exhibits, but it was all good. The restaurant is fabulous and I would recommend it even if you don't go to the museum itself (though I can't imagine why you wouldn't!).
Very knowledgable about life of the indigenous inhabitants , present environment. Specimen exhibited very attractive. A very good place worth to spend an hour or so to visit around.

The animal dioramas and all information that is provided along with it are excellent. We had two hours left hefore we were going to fly back home, and really enjoyed our visit. Nice for kids as well, including a special area where they can dress up, play in a tipi, log cabin, etc. well worth a visit, and absolutely free!

This was a lovely museum that look absolutely brand new. We spent over 3 hours here and could have spent more had the cafeteria been open. I had heard that they have terrific, inexpensive meals here, but they were all booked up with an entire group of people.The exhibits were extremely well diaplayed, and some were intereactive. There were...
So impressed by the excellent presentations in this museum - loved it all. Great opportunity to learn about this amazing part of Canada. Do plan to visit for a few hours. Thank you NWT!

If you ever find yourself in Yellowknife, capital of Canada's Northwest Territories, be sure to stop by the Northern Heritage Centre. It was a good collection of northern artifacts - old and modern, first nation and non. It offers a good glimpse into the history and geography of this vast northern land that has shaped Canada's national culture too.The...

Super interpretive and gives a great overview of the culture. Kid's area with dress-up parkas and wall tents sees more than its share of adults as well! Grab lunch at the cafe. You won't be disappointed.

I am a resident and visit the museum regularly. A great place to learn about our history and there are always new exhibits. A good play area for kids while adults stroll around. Excellent restaurant that serves lunch and afternoon tea.
It was interesting and informative. The restaurant in the centre was amazing. Large portions, great prices, and, most importantly, GREAT food!!

A few of us out-of-towners and some local colleagues popped in for lunch at the museum (the food at the museum restaurant is VERY good by the way) and we were impressed with the quality of the exhibits. While it's not a massive building, the displays we saw were very well done and extremely interesting. The gigantic moosehide canoe was...

This was a very informative center. Lots of exhibits on the natives, animals, minerals and history of the area. A great video on the construction and use of a moose skin canoe. One can easily spend hours there.
The museum is great place to begin your tour of Yellowknife. It will give you a great overview of the local history and the exhibits are quite interesting and authentic.
A small but very nice museum in a small town lacking of tourist attractions beyond the Northern Lights and surrounding nature.
Situated on a short but spectacular lake walk, the museum beautifully presents exhibits and dioramas to show life in the north. This is a must see!

This a a spot that this well worth a visit when in Yellowknife. We encountered a number of different exhibits that provided us with a view of the culture and heritage of this important city in the country's north.Don't miss the films that are available throughout the building - especially the Dene Hand Games and the film on Prospecting...
This was a fabulous place to visit. Give yourself lots of time. We learned so much about the people and the history of the north.

Wow...honestly I think I enjoyed this "museum" better than any other I have been in. Extremely interesting, well laid out and lots of interactive displays. I went in twice! The cafe wasn't open when we were there, I bet it would be nice. Well worth the effort, and well worth a nice donation to help them continue!
Liked:9 first nations languages in NWT,Meaning of "Yellowknife"dry,warm winds,clean water,diamonds,clear light til 12 midnight,sunrise at 5:30

This is a great way to spend a couple of hours if you have a flight layover. The First Nation history and culture exhibits are an excellent introduction to the region. Also good insight into coping in a remote environment and natural history, It is beautifully done and a short walk from downtown. There is a snack bar for a...

Well worth an hour or more for the visiting tourist. Excellent exhibits range from First Nation peoples to natural history to industry of the North. Very well done. No cost. Donation opportunity available. Short walk from city center. Beautiful site. Easy walk from YK center.

I've been in and out of the North for 15 years and there was plenty for me to learn here. I enjoyed the exhibits and the attention to detail. The kids' area was quite good and I especially appreciated the safe boating messaging in that area. Well done!

I don't like most Heritage Centers, but this one has something for everyone. We spent 2 hours just reading, and looking at all the great collect and stories about the area. Well worth the time, and don't forget to donate.

The displays are grand! The staff friendly! The displays change and are very interesting. Count on spending the better part of the day here checking out the displays. The food was great here as well. best mushrooms soup in town in my opinion!

We visited the Heritage Centre the day we were leaving. If we could do it all over again I'd go at the start. Very interesting and informative and great way to better appreciate Yellowknife, it's history and people. Not a great deal of interactive displays or talks, but items on display were of great significance and importance. Highly recommend any...

Museum is well laid out with wheelchair access. Has some nice taxidermy displays of northern animals, and displays that explain the history of the North inhabitants. While we roamed, there were not any interpretive talks taking place, if there had been think it would have been more interesting. As it turned out for us it was a nice warm spot...
This is a first rate interesting museum with many Northern novelties to learn about. We also talked to some of the professional staff who were very nice and helpful.
From the beginning of Yellowknife to present day, the center walks you thru the history and growth of the city and surrounding area.

We learned a lot at this museum about the history of First Nation peoples as well as general history about the area. We went the first full day we had here. It is a great introduction to the NWT, especially for people who know little about the history. It only takes about an hour to an hour and a half...
This place is good for about one hour of touring. Interesting to hear about the history and different groups of people.

Possibly the most worthwhile setup I have ever seen. We spent about two and a half hours viewing the displays and getting a great picture of how the North "worked". The diaramas were very life-like, especially the polar bear chewing on on a seal! The whole building is so well set up that they could charge a goodly admission and...
Entrance is free with a donation. Very interesting museum, learn about the history of the NWT, culture and wildlife.
Some exhibits weren't arranged as well as they could, but there were some really interesting artifacts, animals, mementos, etc.
Extremely good and informative displays. Some excellent videos that were well worth watching. We spent about 3 hours there. Very rewarding
Didn't expect this free museum will have much, but it is actually quite big of a place with a lot to see! Remember to give a donation before you leave the place!

We had a great time at the Heritage Centre. We spent parts of two days going around this location. Reading the history and looking at the displays and watching the videos was very interesting. We spent 2 rainy afternoons here and got a lot out of it. If you are going to do it in a day you will want...
I admit im not a museum person but i found the displays very well done and informative. Well laid out and provides an excellent overview of life in the north.

Nice little museum. I liked the displays but they could use more as the displays of the aviation looked light for the rich heritage the bush pilots had in forming the North. There was only one person on duty that I could see and he was watching the front doors, so no-one available to answer questions. I recommend putting aside...
We learned a lot about Yellowknife's history and their current industry with diamond drilling - very very interesting! Make sure to stop. Beautiful new building and exhibits are very interesting.
We spent a great morning here on a rainy day learning about Yellowknife and the NWT.

I am proud to say Yellowknife has such an excellent museum for such a small town. If you want to learn about the North, its history, people and culture then go to PWNHC. If that does not interest you, go just to see the full-sized polar bear in the entrance or the bush plane or dogsled or just go for...
Loved the displays and information about the north and Yellowknife. They also have art and events that make it worth the visit
some of the sections like northern animals, wildlife photography, northern fairy tales are very good.nice place to spend your free time especially in the winter.

Excellent showcase of what life is like in the north, and the people who were instrumental in shaping its future. Stories and photos are on display showing the way of life and how hard it was to survive in such a brutal land. One of the most interesting displays is a very long map of the entire MacKenzie River system...

Does not have a big collection considering the fact that a number of Native Indian tribes lived and flourished in the area.A lot of the information is given from a European point of view. Construction is still ongoing. Hoping that they can come up to give more emphasis to an amazing culture which the rest of Canada destroyed without any...
Super friendly, and super helpful - you need to take a walk in here and talk to the staff and check out the centre.
Bigger than I thought. Many places to take good pictures. Some stuffed animals are impressive.
Beautiful building with well presented facts and history about the area

The Prince of Wales Northern Heritage Centre is a great museum. Admission is free, though we gladly made a donation, which was very well-deserved.Usually the museums I've visited have been overrun with people. This one was blessedly quiet and uncluttered, and we saw very few people as we wandered from one room to the next. It was almost like...

Make sure you stop by when you are in Yellowknife. This is an excellent museum, with interesting displays that evoke the North very well. It is a great building, with first-rate exhibits. Well worth the time!
The Heritage Centre is worth the trip to see artifacts, exhibits and learn the history of Yellowknife. Admission is free, a great place to visit with the family.
Had some down time so I went to the Price of Wales Heritage Centre.You'll find some nice exhibits, artifacts and a lot of great artwork.

Free and not to be missed if you have the time while here in Yellowknife. The exhibits give a great feel for the north including ones on the aviation history here as well as mining. There's interesting aurora displays and explanations as well the oft discussed giant beaver skull. Who would have thought there used to be beavers up north...

A very unique trip into the history of the northwest territories. A young territory but with extreme heroism and adventures that is well displayed in many different displays. A history of flight in the north is very cool... the diamond discovery displays are neat. Alot of mining and local native history makes the experience a fun and informative one. The...
